questions.text: Pruritus is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Pityriasis versicolor, a superficial fungal infection, usually causes mild or no pruritus, and patients often present due to cosmetic concerns (hypo- or hyperpigmented macules) rather than itching. Atopic dermatitis, lichen planus, and urticaria are well-known for causing intense pruritus.

Dermatological Causes of Pruritus:

Autoimmune causes:

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis
  • Pemphigoid
  • Sjogren's syndrome

Infectious causes:

  • Dermatophytosis
  • Insect bites
  • Pediculosis
  • Scabies

Neoplastic causes:

  • Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (Mycosis fungoides)
  • Leukemia cutis

Genetic causes:

  • Darter's disease
  • Hailey-Hailey disease

Inflammatory causes:

  • Atopic dermatitis
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Drug reactions
  • Lichen planus
  • Mastocytosis
  • Miliaria
  • Keloid scar
  • Urticaria

Pregnancy causes: Pemphigoid gestationis

Explanation of other options:

Atopic dermatitis (Option A): Atopic dermatitis is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory skin condition often associated with a personal or family history of atopy (asthma, allergic rhinitis). It presents with dry skin and intense pruritus, which is a core diagnostic feature. The itch precedes the rash and drives the itch-scratch cycle, leading to lichenification.

Lichen planus (Option B): Lichen planus is an idiopathic inflammatory skin disorder characterized by violaceous, polygonal, flat-topped papules commonly affecting wrists, ankles, and mucosa. It is almost always intensely pruritic, often prompting the patient to seek care.

Urticaria (Option C): Urticaria is a hypersensitivity reaction that manifests as transient wheals due to histamine-mediated vascular leakage. It is classically associated with acute onset of itching, making pruritus a hallmark symptom of the disease.

Key Takeaways:

Not all skin conditions with visible lesions are pruritic. While inflammatory and allergic conditions like atopic dermatitis, lichen planus, and urticaria are notoriously itchy, conditions like pityriasis versicolor usually are not.

choices.text: All eczema is dermatitis, but not all dermatitis is eczema
Acute eczema is typically oedematous, vesicular and may be exudative
Chronic eczema shows spongiosis on histopathology

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding eczema.
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Eczema is a type of dermatitis, characterized by inflammation and pruritus. It evolves through stages. Acute eczema clinically presents with erythema, edema, vesicles, and oozing. Chronic eczema is characterized by lichenification, scaling, and dryness, due to prolonged scratching.

Histopathological hallmark:

  • Spongiosis (Intraepidermal intercellular edema) is a hallmark of acute eczema.
  • Acanthosis (epidermal hyperplasia) dominates chronic eczema.

Explanation of other options:

  • All eczema is dermatitis, but not all dermatitis is eczema (Option A): Eczema refers to a subset of inflammatory skin conditions that are typically itchy and chronic. Dermatitis is a broader term that includes eczema but also encompasses non-eczematous inflammatory conditions. Hence, all eczema qualifies as dermatitis, but not all dermatitis is specifically eczema.
  • Pruritus is universally seen (Option B): Pruritus is a universal symptom in all types of eczema and is considered one of the hallmarks. The severity of pruritus may vary but it is always present.
  • Acute eczema is typically oedematous, vesicular and may be exudative (Option C): Acute eczema classically presents with erythema, oedema, and vesicles which may rupture to form exudative lesions. This is due to acute inflammation and intercellular edema (spongiosis) in the epidermis.

Key Takeaways:

Spongiosis is characteristic of acute eczema, while acanthosis is seen in chronic eczema.

questions.text: A 65 year old man presents with a chronic itching at the site of wearing the watch. All of the following clinical features will be seen except
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Chronic localized itching at the site of wearing a watch this presentation is characteristic of chronic allergic contact dermatitis. It is commonly triggered by nickel exposure from watch straps. Prolonged scratching in such cases leads to lichenification. Lichenification refers to a chronic skin change secondary to persistent scratching or rubbing.

It is defined by:

  • Thickening of the epidermis. Importantly, skin thinning is not observed in this condition.
  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Prominent skin markings (lichenification)
  • Dryness (xerosis)
  • HPE: Acanthosis, increased thickness of stratum spinosum

Explanation of Other Options:

Hyperpigmentation (Option A): Chronic scratching induces post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation.

Increased skin markings (Option B): Lichenification is characterised by exaggerated skin markings due to epidermal hyperplasia.

Xerosis (Option D): Dryness of skin is frequently associated with chronic dermatitis and lichenified lesions.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lichenification is a response to chronic scratching and is associated with thickened, hyperpigmented, dry skin with increased markings.
  • Skin thinning is not a feature and should raise suspicion for other diagnoses or steroid-induced changes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old hospital janitor presents with redness, dryness, and cracking of both hands, especially over the fingers and dorsum as shown in the image. He reports a recent change in the disinfectant used to clean the floor. Which of the following statements about his condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

This patient's presentation of dryness, redness, and cracking of the hands, especially with recent exposure to a new disinfectant, strongly suggests Irritant Contact Dermatitis (ICD). ICD results from direct toxic damage to the skin, not from an immune mechanism. Hence, describing it as a Type IV delayed hypersensitivity is incorrect, this reaction applies to Allergic Contact Dermatitis (ACD), not ICD.

Irritant Contact Dermatitis (ICD)

  • Symptoms: Dryness, redness, and cracking of the hands.
  • Trigger: Recent exposure to a new disinfectant.
  • Mechanism: Direct toxic damage to the skin, not an immune reaction.
  • Most common form of occupational skin disease, especially among healthcare and janitorial workers.
  • Cause: Exposure to irritants (e.g., soaps, solvents, disinfectants) that disrupt the skin barrier, leading to inflammation.

Key Takeaway:

ICD is a non-allergic, non-immune-mediated dermatitis due to chemical injury, whereas ACD is immune-mediated (Type IV) and requires prior sensitization.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with pruritic, erythematous papules and lichenification over her earlobes and the area around her umbilicus. She reports that the symptoms worsen when she wears certain types of jewelry and her favorite jeans. She has no history of atopic dermatitis or systemic autoimmune disease. Which of the following is the most likely allergen causing her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

This is a classic case of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) due to nickel, the most common metal allergen worldwide. Nickel is found in inexpensive jewelry, belt buckles, jean buttons, and even certain medical implants. The presence of dermatitis on the earlobes and umbilicus strongly suggests contact with nickel-containing metal.

  • Metal allergies happen after skin has been in contact with metal. They are a form of allergic contact dermatitis Metal allergies are type IV allergies; the metals are haptens.
  • Nickel allergy and allergies to mercury and chromium have long been recognised; gold, palladium, and cobalt have gotten attention more recently
  • Over nickel is the most common metal cause of ACD
  • Prevention and treatment consists of avoiding the metal allergen.

Explanation for Other options:

Chromium (Option A): Often implicated in cement and leather allergy, particularly in construction workers or those handling industrial materials. It is less likely to be involved in allergic reactions at sites like the earlobes or umbilicus.

Silver (Option C): Rarely causes contact dermatitis. It is generally considered hypoallergenic, and allergic reactions to silver are extremely uncommon.

Cobalt (Option D): Can cause allergic contact dermatitis but is less common than nickel.

Key Takeaway:

  • Nickel is the most common cause of metal-related ACD.
  • Common contact points: earlobes (earrings), umbilicus (jeans/buttons), neck (chains), wrist (watches)
  • Patch testing is diagnostic.
  • It is a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction (T-cell mediated).
  • Avoidance of nickel-containing items is the primary management.

questions.text: A 35 year old lady with a history of hair dye application presents with the following clinical picture. What is the cause
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The clinical presentation of an acute eczematous reaction on the scalp, ears, and neck following hair dye application is highly characteristic of an allergic contact dermatitis. Among the given options, p-Phenylenediamine (PPD) is the most common and potent sensitizer found in permanent hair dyes and is a well-known cause of severe allergic contact dermatitis from hair dye products.

p-Phenylenediamine (PPD): This is a primary allergen in permanent hair dyes.

  • Clinical Presentation: Allergic reactions typically manifest as acute eczematous dermatitis (redness, swelling, itching, blistering, oozing) on the scalp, hairline, face, ears, and neck.
  • Severity: Reactions can range from mild irritation to severe swelling of the face and airways (angioedema), requiring urgent medical attention.
  • Mechanism: PPD is a hapten that penetrates the skin and binds to endogenous proteins, forming a complete antigen that triggers a type IV (delayed-type) hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Testing: Patch testing with PPD is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Isothiazolinones(Option A): These are common preservatives (e.g., methylisothiazolinone, methylchloroisothiazolinone) found in a wide range of cosmetics, household products, and industrial products. While they are potent sensitizers and a common cause of contact dermatitis, they are not typically the primary allergen associated with hair dye reactions specifically.

Formaldehyde-releasing preservatives (Option C): These preservatives (e.g., quaternium-15, DMDM hydantoin) slowly release formaldehyde, which is a known allergen. They can cause contact dermatitis, but they are less frequently the sole cause of acute, severe reactions specifically from hair dyes compared to PPD.

Propylene glycol (Option D): This is a humectant and solvent widely used in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and foods. It can cause irritant contact dermatitis or, less commonly, allergic contact dermatitis, but it is generally considered a weaker sensitizer compared to PPD and is not the signature allergen for hair dye reactions.

Key Takeaway:

In cases of acute eczematous reactions following hair dye application, p-Phenylenediamine (PPD) is the most common and significant causative allergen due to its widespread use in permanent hair dyes and its potent sensitizing capabilities.

questions.text: A mason presents with these lesions on the hands as shown in the image. A patch test is done. Which of the following allergens is most likely to be positive ?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The image shows a construction worker (mason) with erythematous, dry, and hyperkeratotic plaques predominantly over the palms. This pattern is strongly suggestive of occupational contact dermatitis, particularly due to repeated exposure to cement. The primary sensitizing agent in cement is potassium dichromate, a compound of hexavalent chromium. Upon skin contact, it acts as a hapten and induces a Type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction.

Explanation of Other Options:

Nickel (Option B): Nickel is a common allergen but is typically associated with jewelry and clothing accessories, not occupational exposure in masonry.

Cobalt (Option C): Though cobalt may be present in cement, it is a less frequent sensitizer compared to chromium.

Iron (Option D): Iron is not known to cause allergic contact dermatitis.

Key Takeaway:

Potassium dichromate (chromium) is the principal allergen responsible for allergic contact dermatitis in cement workers, especially masons.

questions.text: A female has an itchy rash on forehead. Which of the following is the most probable chemical associated?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The image shows a hyperpigmented, scaly plaque over the center of the forehead, corresponding to the typical site of sticker bindi application in females. The lesion is associated with itching, suggesting allergic contact dermatitis.

  • The principal sensitizing agent is para-tertiary butyl phenol (PTBP), which has both melanocytotoxic and allergenic properties.
  • PTBP causes:
    • Allergic contact dermatitis with itching and erythema
    • Chemical leukoderma due to destruction of melanocytes
  • The sticker bindis are made up of circular discs of polyvinylchloride (PVC) and the adhesive material contains para-tertiary butyl phenol (PTBP)
  • This chemical causes depigmentation through their melanocytotoxic effect leading to chemical leucoderma.
  • And this is also an allergen implicated in causation of contact dermatitis due to bindi - bindi dermatitis

Explanation of Other Options:

Hydroquinone (Option A): Hydroquinone is a depigmenting agent used in skin-lightening creams. It does not typically cause bindi dermatitis.

Mono-benzene metabolite of hydroquinone (Option B): Though it can cause chemical leukoderma, it is not used in bindis but used to make rubber products like rubber gloves and sandals/slippers.

Para Tertiary butyl catechol (Option C): PTBC is used in rubber and plastic industries but is not the primary allergen in bindi adhesives.

Key Takeaway:

PTBP (para-tertiary butyl phenol) is the primary chemical allergen responsible for bindi dermatitis, often presenting with contact dermatitis and localized depigmentation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male farmer from central India presents with chronic itching, erythematous scaly plaques on his face, neck, and forearms. He reports that the rash worsens with fieldwork, especially during the dry season. What is the most likely responsible for his condition?:
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

This is the most common cause of plant induced dermatitis (phytodermatitis) in India

Parthenium hysterophorus (Congress Grass) is the most common cause of phytodermatitis (plant-induced allergic contact dermatitis) in India.

  • Mechanism of Spread: It spreads primarily via airborne pollen and plant particles.
  • Clinical Presentation: Chronic exposure leads to airborne contact dermatitis, typically affecting exposed areas such as the face, neck, and forearms.
  • Key Allergenic Component: The major allergenic compounds responsible for its dermatitic effect are Sesquiterpene lactones.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cotton fibres (Option A): Cotton fibres may cause mechanical irritation but are not known to cause allergic phytodermatitis.

Poison ivy (Option B): While poison ivy is a well-known cause of phytodermatitis in North America, it is not prevalent in India.

Ragweed (Option D): Ragweed is a cause of allergic rhinitis (hay fever) in Western countries but is not a common agent of dermatitis in India.

Key Takeaway:

In India, Parthenium grass is the leading plant allergen causing airborne allergic contact dermatitis, especially in agricultural workers and rural populations.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presents with itchy lichenified rash over face, neck and V area of chest for the last 3 years which exacerbates in summers and improves in winters. What test can be done to confirm diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The clinical presentation of a chronic itchy rash over photo-exposed areas like the face, neck, and 'V' area of the chest, which conspicuously exacerbates in summers and improves in winters, strongly suggests photoallergic contact dermatitis.

  • This condition is a specific type of delayed-type IV hypersensitivity reaction where an allergen, when exposed to light (often UVA), becomes photosensitizing.
  • A photopatch test is the gold standard diagnostic procedure for photoallergic contact dermatitis.
  • Patch test reading is done at 48 and 96 hours
  • It precisely identifies the allergen by applying it to two separate skin sites, irradiating only one site with UV light (typically UVA), and comparing the reactions.
  • A positive reaction exclusively on the irradiated side confirms photoallergy.
  • The rash's predilection for sun-exposed areas and sparing of photo-protected sites (like Wilkinson's triangle) further supports this diagnosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

  1. IgE levels (Option A): IgE levels are relevant for diagnosing Type I (immediate) hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., atopic dermatitis, urticaria, anaphylaxis). Photoallergic contact dermatitis is a Type IV (delayed) hypersensitivity reaction, which is not mediated by IgE.
  2. Skin biopsy (Option B): A skin biopsy would show non-specific eczematous features typical of dermatitis (e.g., spongiosis, lymphocytic infiltrate). While it can confirm inflammation, it does not identify the specific causative allergen or distinguish between photoallergic and other forms of dermatitis.
  3. Prick Test (Option C): The prick test is used for diagnosing Type I (immediate) hypersensitivity reactions to common environmental allergens (e.g., pollens, dust mites, foods). It detects IgE-mediated reactions within minutes and is not suitable for diagnosing delayed-type (Type IV) hypersensitivity conditions like photoallergic contact dermatitis.

Key Takeaway:

When a patient presents with a chronic eczematous rash that is primarily located in sun-exposed areas and worsens with sun exposure, photoallergic contact dermatitis should be strongly suspected. The definitive diagnostic test for this condition is the photopatch test.

questions.text: Patch test is a type of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Patch test detects antigens (allergens) responsible for allergic contact dermatitis (type IV hypersensitivity/ delayed type hypersensitivity)

The test relies on the allergen being absorbed in sufficient quantity to induce a reproducible inflammation of the skin at the site of application in sensitized subjects.

questions.text: A 55 year old farmer, with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and hypertension, developed a severe itchy rash on face, arms and legs. The most appropriate drug for his treatment would be -
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

This patient is a 55-year-old farmer with widespread itchy rash over face, arms, and legs, suggestive of airborne contact dermatitis (ABCD)- a type IV hypersensitivity. Given his comorbidities of uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension, systemic corticosteroids pose significant risk (worsening glycemic and BP control). Therefore, azathioprine is the preferred agent in this case as a steroid-sparing immunosuppressive, effective for extensive or recalcitrant contact dermatitis, particularly when steroids are contraindicated.

Treatment of Allergic contact dermatitis

  1. Topical corticosteroids in combination with oral antihistamines are effective in most cases.
  2. Extensive contact dermatitis may require treatment with a short course of oral corticosteroids.
  3. In air-borne contact dermatitis, azathioprine may be effective, especially as a steroid sparing agent in patients with contraindications to steroid therapy

As corticosteroids are contraindicated in patients with DM and hypertension, the best option here would be azathioprine.

Explanation of Other Options:

Systemic corticosteroids (Option A): Although effective in widespread contact dermatitis, they are not suitable here due to risk of hyperglycemia and hypertension, which are already uncontrolled in this patient.

Thalidomide (Option B): Has immunomodulatory effects but is not a first-line agent in ABCD. It is reserved for special indications like prurigo nodularis or erythema nodosum leprosum due to its side-effect profile (teratogenicity, neuropathy).

Cyclosporine (Option D): Another immunosuppressive agent that could be used for severe dermatitis but is nephrotoxic and hypertensive, making it unsuitable for a patient with hypertension.

Key Takeaway:

Azathioprine is preferred in chronic airborne contact dermatitis in patients who have contraindications to corticosteroids, such as diabetes mellitus and hypertension, due to its relatively safer profile in long-term

questions.text: Which of the following is an endogenous eczema?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Atopic dermatitis is classified as an endogenous eczema, meaning it originates from internal factors such as genetic predisposition, immune dysregulation, and barrier dysfunction. It is commonly associated with other atopic conditions like asthma and allergic rhinitis. Unlike exogenous eczema, there is no need for an external allergen or irritant to initiate the disease.

Eczema (dermatitis) can be classified based on whether the cause is internal (endogenous) or external (exogenous):

  • Endogenous eczema arises due to genetic, immunologic, or systemic internal factors.
  • Exogenous eczema is triggered by external agents such as allergens, irritants, or light exposure.

Atopic dermatitis is a classic example of endogenous eczema, influenced by genetic predisposition, impaired skin barrier, and immune dysregulation. It is frequently associated with asthma and allergic rhinitis.

Etiological Classification of Eczema

Endogenous eczema:

  • Seborrheic dermatitis
  • Nummular/Discoid dermatitis
  • Lichen simplex chronicus
  • Pityriasis alba
  • Stasis dermatitis
  • Atopic dermatitis

Exogenous eczema:

  • Contact Irritant dermatitis
  • Allergic dermatitis
  • Photodermatitis

Explanation of Other Options:

Photodermatitis (Option A): This is an exogenous eczema, triggered by external exposure to UV radiation or photosensitizing agents. It is not caused by internal immune mechanisms.

Contact dermatitis (Option B): This refers to either irritant or allergic contact dermatitis, both of which are exogenous as they result from direct contact with external substances like chemicals or allergens.

Infective eczema (Option D): This arises due to secondary infection (bacterial or fungal) and is also considered exogenous, as the infection comes from an external pathogen.

Key Takeaways:

Atopic dermatitis is an endogenous eczema, while photodermatitis, contact dermatitis, and infective eczema are exogenous, caused by external environmental factors.

questions.text: A 4 year old child presents with the following lesions over face as shown in the image. His mother has a history of bronchial asthma. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

  • The image shows a child with dry, scaly, eczematous lesions predominantly over the face, and cheek involvement. The history mentions that the mother has bronchial asthma, which is a key atopic background. This clinical scenario, along with family history, points strongly toward a diagnosis of atopic dermatitis.
  • Atopic dermatitis (AD) is a chronic, pruritic, relapsing inflammatory skin disease commonly seen in childhood. It is often associated with a personal or family history of atopy (asthma, allergic rhinitis, or eczema).
  • Scratching worsens symptoms and affected patients have an increased risk of skin infections.
  • Cause : genetics (filaggrin deficiency), immune system dysfunction, environmental exposures and skin barrier dysfunction

The distribution of atopic dermatitis (AD) changes with age:

  • Infantile phase (0-2 years): Face, scalp, extensor surfaces
  • Childhood/juvenile phase (2-12 years): Flexural areas like antecubital and popliteal fossae
  • Adolescent/adult phase (>12 years): Flexural areas, face, neck, hands

Explanation of Other Options:

Infantile eczematous dermatitis (Option A): This term is often used interchangeably with atopic dermatitis but specifically refers to presentation in infants under 2 years. At 4 years of age, the condition is better classified as atopic dermatitis in early childhood.

Seborrheic dermatitis (Option B): Typically affects sebaceous-rich areas like the scalp, nasolabial folds, and postauricular regions with greasy, yellowish scales-not the dry, eczematous plaques over the cheeks as seen here.

Airborne contact dermatitis (Option C): Commonly affects older children and adults, usually presenting with dermatitis over exposed areas such as the eyelids, neck, and arms, and is often seasonal. It is uncommon at this young age.

Key Takeaways:

Atopic dermatitis in children often begins with facial involvement and is strongly associated with a personal or family history of atopic diseases like asthma or allergic rhinitis.

questions.text: The Hanifin and Rajka criteria is used in the diagnosis of _____
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Atopic dermatitis is a clinical diagnosis. To standardize diagnosis, the Hanifin and Rajka criteria were developed and are still regarded as the gold standard. Many modifications have been developed, such as the United Kingdom working party criteria.

Major criteria (3 or more required):

Pruritus

Typical morphology and distribution:

  • Flexural lichenification or linearity in adults
  • Facial and extensor involvement in infants and children
    Chronic or chronically-relapsing dermatitis
    Personal or family history of atopy (asthma, allergic rhinitis, atopic dermatitis)

Minor criteria (3 or more required):

  • Xerosis
  • Ichthyosis, palmar hyperlinearity, or keratosis pilaris
  • Immediate (type 1) skin-test reactivity
  • Raised serum IgE
  • Early age of onset
  • Tendency toward cutaneous infections (especially Staphylococcus aureus and herpes simplex) or impaired cell-mediated immunity
  • Tendency toward non-specific hand or foot dermatitis
  • Nipple eczema
  • Cheilitis
  • Recurrent conjunctivitis
  • Dennie-Morgan infraorbital fold
  • Keratoconus
  • Anterior subcapsular cataracts
  • Orbital darkening
  • Facial pallor or facial erythema
  • Pityriasis alba
  • Anterior neck folds
  • Itch when sweating
  • Intolerance to wool and lipid solvents
  • Perifollicular accentuation
  • Food intolerance
  • Course influenced by environmental or emotional factors
  • White dermographism or delayed blanch

Explanation of Other Options:

Nummular eczema (Option B): Presents as coin-shaped plaques, usually in adults or elderly, and does not follow the distribution or chronic relapsing nature of atopic dermatitis. Diagnosis is clinical, based on morphology, not criteria-based.

Stasis eczema (Option C): Occurs due to venous insufficiency, typically in the lower limbs of elderly patients. It is associated with edema, hyperpigmentation, and sometimes ulceration. Diagnosis is based on vascular findings, not on Hanifin and Rajka criteria.

Contact dermatitis (Option D): Caused by allergen or irritant exposure, leading to localized erythema, itching, or vesicles. Diagnosis is confirmed by patch testing in allergic forms. It is not related to atopy and doesn't use Hanifin and Rajka for diagnosis.

Key Takeaways:

Hanifin and Rajka criteria are used only for atopic dermatitis, not for other types of eczema.
AD typically presents in childhood, especially with a family history of atopy.

questions.text: Major clinical feature in diagnosis of atopic dermatitis A/E -
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Pruritus is a major criterion in the Hanifin and Rajka criteria for diagnosing atopic dermatitis.
The Hanifin and Rajka criteria are the gold standard for diagnosing atopic dermatitis, dividing diagnostic features into:

Major criteria

  • Pruritus
  • Chronic or relapsing dermatitis
  • Typical morphology and distribution
  • Personal or family history of atopy

Minor criteria (supportive features):

  • Dry skin (xerosis)
  • Dennie-Morgan folds (infraorbital lines)
  • Pityriasis alba
  • Elevated serum IgE, early onset, susceptibility to skin infections, etc.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dry skin (xerosis) (Option A): This is a minor criterion and commonly seen in atopic individuals due to skin barrier dysfunction.

Morgan fold (Dennie-Morgan lines) (Option C): These are infraorbital skin folds, a minor criterion often seen in children with atopic dermatitis.

Pityriasis alba (Option D): A minor criterion, commonly seen in children with atopic background, especially over cheeks, presenting as hypopigmented scaly patches.

Key Takeaways:

Pruritus is a major feature, not minor, in diagnosing atopic dermatitis.
Dry skin, Morgan folds, and pityriasis alba are part of the minor criteria in Hanifin and Rajka.
Understanding which features are major vs minor is essential for accurately diagnosing and classifying atopic dermatitis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with a long history of intensely itchy rashes, particularly in the creases of their elbows and knees. The skin appears dry and thickened in these areas. During a physical examination, the physician gently strokes the child's forearm with a tongue depressor. Initially, a faint red line appears, but within seconds, this redness is replaced by a distinct, blanching white line as shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The image shows a linear white mark on an erythematous background created by stroking the skin with a blunt object, forming an "X" pattern. This is a classical feature of white dermographism.  On stroking the skin of atopic individuals, the rubbed area becomes erythematous, but the erythema is replaced in 10-15 seconds by pallor, which may persist for 60 seconds or more . This phenomenon is called 'white dermographism' and is considered an abnormal vascular response in patients with atopic dermatitis.

White dermographism: On stroking the skin of atopic individuals, the rubbed area becomes erythematous, but the erythema is replaced in 10-15 seconds by pallor, which may persist for 60 seconds or more . This phenomenon is called 'white dermographism' and is considered an abnormal vascular response in patients with atopic dermatitis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Chronic urticaria (Option A): Typically shows positive (red) dermographism, where stroking the skin leads to raised, red, itchy wheals. It does not cause white dermographism.

Angioedema (Option C): Presents with deep, diffuse swelling, usually of the eyelids, lips, or face. It involves the deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissues and does not produce white dermographism.

Pressure from a metallic object (Option D): May cause temporary linear indentations or erythema but does not trigger the neurovascular reflex seen in white dermographism. The effect is purely mechanical and not diagnostic.

Key Takeaways:

White dermographism is a hallmark of atopic dermatitis, not seen in urticaria or angioedema.

It reflects altered neurovascular reactivity of the skin and is a valuable clinical diagnostic clue in atopic individuals.

Urticaria causes red dermographism, while mechanical pressure only causes transient changes without the vascular phenomenon.

questions.text: The most common cause of skin infection in Atopic Dermatitis individuals is A 9-year-old child with a history of atopic dermatitis presents with sudden worsening of a previously eczematous lesion as shown in the image. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The clinical image shows atopic dermatitis with secondary bacterial infection. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism responsible for secondary bacterial infection in atopic dermatitis

Atopic dermatitis is characterized by skin barrier dysfunction, immune dysregulation, and colonization by microbes. There is increased risk of skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs) such as:

  • Impetigo
  • Cellulitis
  • Abscesses

The most common cause of these infections is S aureus.In addition, S aureus produces enterotoxins (superantigens) that are known to break down the skin barrier and enhance type 2 inflammation.

Up to 90% of patients with AD are colonized with S aureus.

Explanation of Other Options:

Herpes Simplex Virus 1 and 2 (Option B): HSV causes eczema herpeticum, a potentially severe complication of atopic dermatitis. It presents as painful, monomorphic vesicles with hemorrhagic crusting, not just sudden flare of eczematous lesions. It is less common than bacterial superinfection.

Streptococcus pyogenes (Option C): While it can cause impetigo and cellulitis, it is less commonly isolated than Staphylococcus aureus in patients with AD.

Trichophyton rubrum (Option D): A dermatophyte that causes tinea infections, such as tinea corporis or pedis. It does not typically infect atopic dermatitis lesions and is not a usual secondary pathogen in these cases.

Key Takeaways:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common pathogen in secondary infections in atopic dermatitis.

Its colonization and toxin production worsen the inflammation and should be treated appropriately.

questions.text: Commonest site of juvenile atopic dermatitis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

In the juvenile phase, the most characteristic and common site is the antecubital fossa, followed by the popliteal fossa and neck.

The distribution of atopic dermatitis (AD) changes with age:

  • Infantile phase (0–2 years): Face, scalp, extensor surfaces. (Option A)(Option B)
  • Childhood/juvenile phase (2–12 years): Flexural areas like antecubital and popliteal fossae
  • Adolescent/adult phase (>12 years): Flexural areas, face, neck, hands

Cubital or antecubital fossa and popliteal fossa along with neck is the common site for Atopic dermatitis in adults

Key Takeaways:

In the childhood/juvenile phase, flexural involvement is typical, especially the antecubital and popliteal fossae.

Recognizing age-dependent patterns of lesion distribution is essential for correctly diagnosing atopic dermatitis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset, sharply demarcated, geometric erythematous lesions over the dorsum of her hand. She reports that the lesions appeared overnight and denies any trauma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Dermatitis artefacta is a condition in which skin lesions are solely produced or inflicted by the patient's own actions. This usually occurs as a result or manifestation of a psychological problem.The condition is also known as factitial dermatitis

  • Patients present with lesions that are difficult to recognise and do not conform to those of known dermatoses.
  • Lesions are often in bizarre shapes with irregular outlines in a linear or geometric pattern,
  • Lesions are usually clearly demarcated from surrounding normal skin.
  • The appearance of lesions varies depending on methods used to injure the skin.
  • Lesions may be produced by a variety of mechanical or chemical means, including fingernails, sharp or blunt objects, lit cigarettes and caustic chemicals.
  • Lesions do not evolve gradually but emerge almost overnight without any prior signs or symptoms.
  • They are usually found on sites that are readily accessible to the patient's hands, e.g. face, hands, arms or legs.
  • The patient will usually deny that the rash is self induced.

Explanation of Other Options:

Atopic dermatitis (Option A): Typically presents with poorly demarcated, lichenified, itchy patches, especially in flexural areas. It evolves gradually and lacks the sudden, geometric pattern seen here.

Lichen planus (Option C): Presents as violaceous, polygonal, flat-topped papules, often with Wickham striae. Lesions are not abrupt or bizarrely shaped, and distribution is usually symmetric and non-self-inflicted.

Insect bite (Option D): Usually appears as urticarial papules or plaques, sometimes with a central punctum. The pattern is random, not geometric or sharply demarcated, and typically pruritic.

Key Takeaways:

Dermatitis artefacta should be suspected when skin lesions:

  • Are sudden in onset, bizarrely shaped, and appear on easily accessible areas
  • Have no clear clinical cause and do not match known dermatoses
  • Are associated with denial and psychological stress
    A thorough psychosocial evaluation is essential in suspected cases.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with chronic relapsing pruritic lesions over the flexural surfaces is diagnosed with atopic dermatitis. The treating physician decides to start treatment. Which of the following topical agents is least appropriate in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Tretinoin, a topical retinoid, is not used in AD. It causes dryness, irritation, and peeling, which can worsen the compromised skin barrier in AD patients. It is primarily indicated for acne vulgaris and photoaging.

Atopic dermatitis is managed with a combination of:

  • Emollients (mainstay for barrier repair)
  • Topical corticosteroids (gold standard, first-line anti-inflammatory)(Option A)
  • Topical calcineurin inhibitors (steroid-sparing agents)(Option B)
  • Crisaborole topical ointment 2% was approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in December 2016 for mild-to-moderate atopic dermatitis in adults and children aged 2 years or older.(Option D)

Key Takeaways:

Tretinoin is contraindicated in atopic dermatitis due to its barrier-damaging and irritating properties.

Topical corticosteroids, calcineurin inhibitors, and PDE-4 inhibitors form the core of topical therapy in AD.

Avoid agents that can further disrupt the skin barrier or provoke irritation in these patients.

questions.text: A 12 year old boy presented with a 10 year history of severe rash over the body and had taken various treatments with suboptimal relief and multiple recurrences. Which of the following drugs can bring improvement in the patient ?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The child presents with a 10-year history of severe, recurrent atopic dermatitis that has shown suboptimal response to conventional therapies, indicating the need for advanced systemic treatment. The clinical scenario fits moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis, especially in a child over 6 years of age-the age group approved for biologic therapy with dupilumab.

Dupilumab is a fully human monoclonal antibody targeting the IL-4 receptor alpha subunit, thereby blocking both IL-4 and IL-13 signaling. These are key cytokines in type 2 inflammation involved in atopic dermatitis. It has been approved by the FDA for adults and children older than 6 years who have moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis not adequately controlled with topical prescription therapies or when those therapies are not advisable. It is a subcutaneous injection administered every 2 weeks.

Explanation of Other Options:

Infliximab (Option A): A TNF-alpha inhibitor used primarily in psoriasis, rheumatoid arthritis, and inflammatory bowel disease. It is not approved for atopic dermatitis and has limited evidence of benefit in this setting.

Secukinumab (Option B): A monoclonal antibody that inhibits IL-17A, indicated for plaque psoriasis, psoriatic arthritis, and ankylosing spondylitis. It is not effective against AD, wh

Omalizumab (Option D): A monoclonal antibody against IgE, used in allergic asthma and chronic spontaneous urticaria. Though AD has an allergic component, omalizumab is not approved for AD, and data on its efficacy is inconsistent.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dupilumab is a FDA-approved biologic for moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis, targeting IL-4 and IL-13.
  • It is indicated in patients over 6 years who fail to respond adequately to topical therapies.

questions.text: A six-year-old child with a history of atopic dermatitis presents to the clinic for evaluation. Some asymptomatic lesions are noticed on extensor surfaces of the proximal upper and lower extremities. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of the Answer:

The image shows numerous small, skin-colored to slightly hyperpigmented follicular papules, most prominent over the extensor surface. Keratosis pilaris is a common, benign follicular disorder characterized by keratin plugging of hair follicles. It is associated with atopic dermatitis and ichthyosis vulgaris, and typically involves:

  • Extensor surfaces of arms and thighs
  • Follicular papules with rough texture ("chicken skin")
  • Onset in childhood or adolescence
  • Often asymptomatic but may be cosmetically concerning
  • Antenna sign: Fine hair protruding from the center of the papule

Explanation of Other Options:

Folliculitis (Option A): This is incorrect. Folliculitis presents with inflamed, erythematous, or pustular papules that may be painful or tender, unlike the non-inflamed, asymptomatic keratotic papules seen in KP.

Phrynoderma (Option B): This is incorrect. Phrynoderma is a follicular hyperkeratotic condition secondary to vitamin A or B complex deficiency, typically affecting elbows, knees, and extensor aspects but usually in malnourished children, with dry skin and lichenoid appearance,(toad skin) not typically associated with atopic history.

Scurvy (Option D): This is incorrect. Scurvy due to vitamin C deficiency presents with perifollicular hemorrhages, corkscrew hairs, ecchymoses, and gingival bleeding, especially in malnourished children, and not with follicular plugging or rough dry papules.

Key Takeaways:

  • Keratosis pilaris presents as rough, dry, asymptomatic follicular papules, often over extensor surfaces in children.
  • It is associated with atopic dermatitis and does not require treatment unless for cosmetic concerns.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with a well-demarcated itchy lesion on his left shin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a well-demarcated, round-to-oval, erythematous plaque with scaling and possible oozing, located on the shin. The lesion appears coin-shaped and intensely pruritic, all of which are hallmark features of nummular eczema.

Nummular eczema, also called discoid eczema, presents with:

  • Pruritic, coin-shaped (nummular) lesions
  • Typically found on extremities, especially legs
  • May be oozing, crusted, or scaly
  • Often occurs in individuals with dry skin
  • Symmetric distribution is common in chronic cases
  • It is more common in adult males and is often exacerbated by winter or skin dryness.

Stasis Dermatitis (Option A): Stasis dermatitis typically affects the lower legs (shins and ankles) but is almost exclusively seen in older individuals with chronic venous insufficiency (e.g., varicose veins, edema, hyperpigmentation from hemosiderin deposition).

Pompholyx (Option C) is characterized by deep-seated vesicles on the palms, soles, and lateral fingers.(sago grain appearance)

Asteatotic eczema (Option D) Also called xerotic eczema, this condition presents with dry, cracked skin and superficial fissuring, typically in older adults, especially during winter. It appears more as a cracked porcelain or crazy-paving pattern.

Learning Point:

Nummular eczema should be suspected in an adult presenting with pruritic, round eczematous plaques over extremities. Unlike fungal infections, the lesions do not have central clearing. Differentiating based on location and morphology is key to diagnosis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a hypopigmented patch on her face with fine scaling. There is no loss of sensation or nerve thickening. There is a history of atopy in the family. What is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The image shows a hypopigmented patch with fine scaling on the cheek of a young child. The lesion is ill-defined, non-indurated, and the child has a positive family history of atopy, is strongly suggestive of pityriasis alba.

Pityriasis alba is a common hypopigmenting disorder in children and adolescents, often considered a minor manifestation of atopic dermatitis.

Clinical features include:

  • Ill-defined, hypopigmented macules or patches
  • Fine scaling may be present
  • Usually asymptomatic or mildly pruritic
  • Common sites: cheeks, chin, and sometimes upper limbs
  • Associated with dry skin and atopic background

Explanation of Other Options:

Indeterminate Leprosy (Option A): Leprosy also presents with hypopigmented patches, but they are typically anesthetic (loss of sensation) and may show nerve thickening, which is not seen in pityriasis alba.

Pityriasis rosea (Option B):Pityriasis rosea starts with a herald patch and then develops multiple oval lesions on the trunk in a "Christmas tree" distribution, not isolated facial patches.

Pityriasis versicolor (Option D): Caused by Malassezia, it presents with scaly hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules, typically on the upper trunk, neck, or arms. It is not usually isolated to the face in children.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pityriasis alba is a benign hypopigmenting disorder common in children with atopic background
  • Presents as ill-defined, mildly scaly, hypopigmented patches usually on the face
